September 17, 1995: Fiction
"L" IS FOR LAWLESS, by Sue Grafton. (Holt, $24.) Kinsey Millhone on the trail of
the cash and the culprits involved in a bank heist perpetrated decades ago.
COMING HOME, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dunne/St. Martin's, $25.95.) A British
woman comes of age during World War II.
FROM POTTER'S FIELD, by Patricia Cornwell. (Scribner, $24.) Dr. Kay Scarpetta
tracks a serial killer in Central Park.
BEACH MUSIC, by Pat Conroy. (Talese/Doubleday, $27.50.) An American living
in Rome returns to South Carolina and tries to cope with his troubled past.
MEMNOCH THE DEVIL, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $25.) The vampire Lestat is
snatched from the world by a mysterious adversary who claims to be the Devil.
THE CELESTINE PROPHECY, by James Redfield. (Warner, $17.95.) An ancient
manuscript, found in Peru, provides insights into achieving a fulfilling life.
DEAD MAN'S WALK, by Larry McMurtry. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) The
adventures of two young Texas Rangers; a prequel to "Lonesome Dove."
LIGHTNING, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $24.95.) The happy marriage of a
lawyer and her husband is suddenly changed after she gets a routine checkup.
THE RAINMAKER, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $25.95.) A young man barely
out of law school tries to expose a corporation's multibillion-dollar scam.
STORMY WEATHER, by Carl Hiaasen. (Knopf, $24.) A hurricane sweeping
across southern Florida leaves in its wake troubled tourists and con artists.
FOR THE ROSES, by Julie Garwood. (Pocket, $23.) A late-19th-century woman
with a checkered past investigates her identity, resulting in romance.
A PLACE CALLED FREEDOM, by Ken Follett. (Crown, $25.) Two Scots, fleeing
the injustices of their native land, seek romance and freedom in 18th-century
America.
THE BRIDGES OF MADISON COUNTY, by Robert James Waller. (Warner,
$17.95.) A photographer and a farmer's lonely wife in Iowa.
ROSE MADDER, by Stephen King. (Viking, $25.95.) Fleeing an abusive husband,
a woman seeks happiness in a strange city by creating her own myth.
GUMP & CO., by Winston Groom. (Pocket, $22.) Forrest Gump continues to
fumble his way through history.
September 17, 1995
Non-Fiction
MY POINT . . . AND I DO HAVE ONE, by Ellen DeGeneres. (Bantam, $19.95.)
Observations on life and the pursuit of happiness by the television star and stand-
up comedian.
A GOOD WALK SPOILED, by John Feinstein. (Little, Brown, $23.95.) A
sportswriter reports on the P.G.A. Tour in 1993 and 1994.
SISTERS. Essays by Carol Saline. Photographs by Sharon J. Wohlmuth.
(Running Press, $27.50.) The relationships of 36 sets of sisters.
MIDNIGHT IN THE GARDEN OF GOOD AND EVIL, by John Berendt. (Random
House, $23.) The mysterious death of a young man in Savannah, Ga.
SPONTANEOUS HEALING, by Andrew Weil. (Knopf, $23.) A physician explains
the ways in which the body heals itself.
MY OLD MAN AND THE SEA, by David Hays and Daniel Hays. (Algonquin,
$19.95.) A sailing yarn about a father-and-son voyage from Connecticut around
Cape Horn.
TO RENEW AMERICA, by Newt Gingrich. (HarperCollins, $24.) The Speaker of
the House describes his solutions to the country's problems.
NEW PASSAGES, by Gail Sheehy. (Random House, $25.) How changing social
conditions and longer life expectancies are affecting our lives.
I'M ONLY ONE MAN! by Regis Philbin with Bill Zehme. (Hyperion, $22.95.) A
memoir by the co-host of "Live With Regis and Kathie Lee."
SLEEPERS, by Lorenzo Carcaterra. (Ballantine, $23.) The true story, the narrator
claims, of four boys in a reformatory and the revenge they later take.
BUFFETT, by Roger Lowenstein. (Random House, $27.50.) The life of Warren
Buffett and how he became one of the country's richest men.
IN THEIR NAME, edited by Clive Irving. (Random House, $25.) The Oklahoma
City bombing: the stories of those it affected, told in words and pictures.
THE HOUSEKEEPER'S DIARY, by Wendy Berry. (Barricade, $19.95.) The lives of
Prince Charles and Princess Diana before their separation, recorded by their
housekeeper.
DAVE BARRY'S COMPLETE GUIDE TO GUYS, by Dave Barry. (Random House,
$21.) A humorist explains the strange ways of a species of males called "guys."
DARK SUN, by Richard Rhodes. (Simon & Schuster, $32.50.) How and why the
hydrogen bomb was made.
